metadata.title: Convert Gigabytes to Megabytes – Decimal & Binary Accurate
metadata.description: Convert GB to MB or GiB to MiB with NIST decimal prefixes, IEC/ISO binary clarity, and quick cues for storage planning, reporting, and data transfers.

gigabytes_to_megabytes_decimal.label: Gigabytes (GB, decimal) to Megabytes (MB)
gigabytes_to_megabytes_decimal.description: For storage labels and cloud billing where 1 GB = 1,000,000,000 bytes and 1 MB = 1,000,000 bytes.

gibibytes_to_mebibytes_binary.description: For OS readouts and file systems where 1 GiB = 1,073,741,824 bytes and 1 MiB = 1,048,576 bytes.

fields.label: Gigabytes (GB)
fields.helpText: Use for decimal gigabytes shown on drive packaging and cloud pricing; 1 GB = 1,000,000,000 bytes.

fields.label: Gibibytes (GiB)
fields.helpText: Use for binary gibibytes shown in operating systems and file explorers; 1 GiB = 1,073,741,824 bytes.

introduction: Convert gigabytes to megabytes or gibibytes to mebibytes instantly with standards-based factors so capacity estimates line up between packaging, cloud invoices, and OS readouts.
We split decimal (GB/MB) and binary (GiB/MiB) paths, anchored to NIST SI prefixes and IEC/ISO binary prefixes, to eliminate confusion when reconciling specs, screenshots, or audit logs.
Field-level guidance keeps engineers, IT admins, and students on the right path whether they are budgeting storage, checking transfer sizes, or documenting a lab exercise.
methodology: Decimal storage uses SI prefixes: 1 gigabyte (GB) = 10^9 bytes and 1 megabyte (MB) = 10^6 bytes, so GB to MB multiplies by 1000 per NIST SI guidance.
Binary storage in operating systems follows IEC/ISO 80000-13 prefixes: 1 gibibyte (GiB) = 2^30 bytes and 1 mebibyte (MiB) = 2^20 bytes, so GiB to MiB multiplies by 1024.

Choose the method that matches your source: vendor labels and cloud billing use decimal, while OS disk utilities and many file systems use binary. For audits, note which prefix system you applied per IEEE 1541 and university computing lab recommendations.
examples: 2.5 GB × 1000 = 2500 MB, matching most drive packaging and cloud plan descriptions.
16 GiB × 1024 = 16384 MiB, aligning with operating-system disk usage reports.
0.75 GB converts to 750 MB for a quick upload allowance check.

faqs.question: Why do GB and GiB give different numbers?
faqs.answer: GB uses decimal prefixes (base 10); GiB uses binary prefixes (base 2). Hardware labels and cloud invoices use GB, while operating systems often show GiB.

faqs.question: Which should I use for compliance or reporting?
faqs.answer: Use the prefix system of your source data: procurement and invoices expect decimal GB/MB; technical troubleshooting and OS screenshots usually need binary GiB/MiB. Record the choice in notes for audit clarity.

faqs.question: Are these conversions exact?
faqs.answer: Yes by definition: multiply by 1000 for GB→MB and by 1024 for GiB→MiB. Any rounding shown is for readability only.

faqs.question: Do network tools report GB or GiB?
faqs.answer: It varies. Some tools report GB/s (decimal), others GiB/s (binary). Check the tool documentation and apply the matching method here.

faqs.question: Can I reverse from MB back to GB?
faqs.answer: Yes. Divide MB by 1000 to get GB, or divide MiB by 1024 to get GiB, keeping the prefix system consistent.

citations.label: ISO/IEC 80000-13: Quantities and units—Information science and technology

glossary.definition: Decimal storage unit equal to 1,000,000,000 bytes (10^9), common on packaging and invoices.
Binary storage unit equal to 1,073,741,824 bytes (2^30), common in operating-system reporting.
Decimal storage unit equal to 1,000,000 bytes (10^6), used in marketing and billing.
Binary storage unit equal to 1,048,576 bytes (2^20), used in file system and OS contexts.
